abstract.p: Tom Hausken letter on Jan 3 article comparing Wikipedia and Encyclopedia Britannica suggests that source is important in determining how much weight to place on information

block.p: Re ''The Nitpicking of the Masses vs. the Authority of the Experts'' (Commentary, Jan. 3):

Users of references -- whether Wikipedia or Britannica, and the broader public for that matter -- should learn that as important as the validity of so-called ''facts'' is the conscious evaluation and citation of the authority behind the claims. Making connection to the source, whether it is a highly trusted historian or an unknown contributor to Wikipedia, allows people to be critical readers. Such connections are essential in academia, law, media and other public discourse.
Re ''The Nitpicking of the Masses vs. the Authority of the Experts'' (Commentary, Jan. 3):

Users of references -- whether Wikipedia or Britannica, and the broader public for that matter -- should learn that as important as the validity of so-called ''facts'' is the conscious evaluation and citation of the authority behind the claims. Making connection to the source, whether it is a highly trusted historian or an unknown contributor to Wikipedia, allows people to be critical readers. Such connections are essential in academia, law, media and other public discourse.

Also, the author presumes that the errors in the Wikipedia will gradually be polished out, while in fact there may be a natural social equilibrium, where new errors naturally arise just as others are corrected. And he presumes that Wikipedia will not eventually be overcome by minority interests that wish to commandeer entries to present their own views. Only time will tell how that plays out.
